1997010:
Frank J Prial Wine Talk column on some likely developments in world of wine in 1997; drawing (M)Professional caterers describe how they make use of leftovers, to try to eliminate waste and cut costs; recipes (M)Buffalo Sabres defeat New Jersey Devils, 6-5, Marine Midland Arena, Buffalo (M)Top Federal Reserve Bank officials can now stay in their jobs longer; in policy change, Federal Reserve System board of governors says it approved changes in rules for tenure of highest officials at 12 regional banks, by adding optional exception to rules that govern their retirement; under new policy, if appointed after age of 55, a Fed bank pres or first vice pres would be allowed to stay in job for 10 years, or until age of 70 (S)Interview with John Cardinal O'Connor, influential Archbishop of New York; as O'Connor approaches his 77th birthday on Jan 15, he sounds like a man preparing to close out his career; he is already two years beyond official retirement age for bishops; he says he regrets his quick tongue, admitting 'I said some dumb things'; excerpts from some of O'Connor's remarks; photos (L)Tanisha Tucker of Bronx is arrested and charged with reckless endangerment in death of her 10-month-old daughter, Delores Tucker, who is found with fractured skill and other injuries indicative of child abuse (M)Nearly half a million people gather on Las Vegas strip to ring in New Year and watch Hacienda Hotel implode; implosion, centerpiece of celebration that rivals New York City's, is preceded by 4 minutes of fireworks; 9 PM implosion coincides with midnight on East Coast; 11-story, 900-room hotel will be replaced by 4,000-room hotel and casino (S)Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel and Yasir Arafat reportedly clinch elusive agreement on Israeli withdrawal from West Bank town of Hebron, but critical Israeli budget debate puts off their final meeting until New Year (M)Profile of Warrick Dunn, Florida State University running back (M)Last day of year disappoints investors looking for stock market to end year with last burst through finish line; photo (L)Long Island Lighting Company's merger agreement with Brooklyn Union Gas provides that Lilco shareholders would get stock price bonus if New York State were to take over $4.5 billion debt for defunct Shoreham nuclear plant; if bonus is included, Lilco owners are likely to see their long-troubled stock rise one-third in value as result of planned merger (M)Cartoons by Steven Appleby depicting New Year on other planets (L)James Goldman, neuroscience major at University of Rochester, who has been juggling since he was teen-ager, has been teaching brain-damaged people to juggle and believes he has discovered a powerful new tool for physical therapy; experience has convinced Goldman that juggling can improve lives of more than 700,000 patients in United States who have suffered neurological damage from accidents, birth defects, strokes, heart attacks or radiation (M)House ethics committee, in apparent setback for Speaker Newt Gingrich, announces that it will not proceed with its two-year investigation into ethics complaints against him until Jan 8, one day after he is to stand for re-election to leadership post; timing puts House Republicans in awkward position of voting for Speaker without benefit of full airing of ethics charges against Gingrich and without knowing how severe a punishment ethics committee will impose (M)About New York column on Darryl Jones, who obtains patent for indoor variation on Skelly, street game using chalk and bottle caps that has been played by generations of New Yorkers; Jones's invention, called Objectional Air Skelly, is played on snazzily painted 4-by-4-foot wooden board whose surface has hundreds of pinholes like air hockey (M)Dallas Stars release veteran right wing Sergei Makarov (S)New Year's Eve scene is celebrated in Times Square; photos (L)Combination of sleet, rain and snow covers roads and highways of New York City region with thin sheet of ice, causing widespread traffic delays and scores of accidents during afternoon rush (S)Aimee Sullivan letter on hostage crisis in Lima, Peru; contends scant attention has been paid to Peruvian Government-sponsored torture, disappearance of opposition activists, and arbitrary imprisonment of innocent peopleSingapore's economy expanded 6.5% in 1996, slowest rate of growth since 1992 (S)Television season reaches its halfway point this week with two familiar trends in place: no new hit has lighted up prime time, and all broadcast networks continue to be hit by mass defections of viewers; yet, in season' most surprising trend, wholesale changes are not in offing; aside from Fox, which dumps all but one of new shows it trotted out in fall, networks seem unusually content with new shows they put in place in September; photos (L)Gabriel Lewis Galindo, Panamanian diplomat and businessman who helped negotiate Panama Canal Treaties, spearheaded efforts to overthrow Gen Manuel Antonio Noriega and served until recently as his country's Foreign Minister, dies at age 68; Clinton Administration won international approval of the two treaties in Geneva in December, 1996, buts concedes that Congressional approval is far from assured (M)Being a debutante is seen regaining its popularity once again for some young women; in contrast to excess spending of 1980's, when debutantes were 'overdone' with lavish dresses and huge diamonds around their necks, this time the entry is more subtle, the gowns simpler; some say it is tied to economy, others say it is a yearning for a romantic period, as end of century approaches, and still others see return of cotillion as quest for civility; photos (M)Richard Bernstein reviews Hilton Als book The Women; photo (M)Sybil Primis, mother of Lance R Primis, former president and chief operating officer of New York Times Co, dies at 87 (S)Interior Deparment takes step toward eliminating intrusions of man into Grand Canyon, restricting aircraft flights in harbinger of overall plan to restrict even automobile traffic at canyon and in some of nation's other heavily traveled parks; Sec Bruce Babbitt announces new restrictions on flights by small airplanes and helicopters that carry tourists over Grand Canyon; but rules are just part of long-contemplated strategy that, if planners have their way, will eventually all but eliminate cars from Grand Canyon and, one day, from other popular national parks; if plan is executed it would be dramatic rethinking of how parks like Grand Canyon in northern Arizona and Yosemite in northern California are managed; postwar vision of national parks as an extension of American automobile culture of freedom and convenience is disappearing; Recovery Inc has expanded internationally and, through 700 groups, now serves hundreds of thousands of people who want to improve their emotional well-being; participants include ordinary people who lives are impaired by anxiety, depression, panic attacks, excessive stress and nervousness who may never have consulted a mental health professional, as well as patients currently or formerly in treatment for serious emotional problems (M)Florence Fabricant Food Notes column (M)Photo of snow-dusted Metro-North tracks at Croton-Harmon yardsNew year promises to be one of most turbulent ever for hospitals and health insurers in New York State, as new law takes effect lifting price controls on hospitals and forcing them to compete in increasingly cutthroat health care market; Sec Bruce Babbitt announces new restrictions on flights by small airplanes and helicopters that carry tourists over Grand Canyon; but rules are just part of long-contemplated strategy that, if planners have their way, will eventually all but eliminate cars from Grand Canyon and, one day, from other popular national parks; if plan is executed it would be dramatic rethinking of how parks like Grand Canyon in northern Arizona and Yosemite in northern California are managed; postwar vision of national parks as an extension of American automobile culture of freedom and convenience is disappearing; if plan is executed it would be dramatic rethinking of how parks like Grand Canyon in northern Arizona and Yosemite in northern California are managed; postwar vision of national parks as an extension of American automobile culture of freedom and convenience is disappearing; if plan is executed it would be dramatic rethinking of how parks like Grand Canyon in northern Arizona and Yosemite in northern California are managed; postwar vision of national parks as an extension of American automobile culture of freedom and convenience is disappearing; Sec Bruce Babbitt announces new restrictions on flights by small airplanes and helicopters that carry tourists over Grand Canyon; but rules are just part of long-contemplated strategy that, if planners have their way, will eventually all but eliminate cars from Grand Canyon and, one day, from other popular national parks; if plan is executed it would be dramatic rethinking of how parks like Grand Canyon in northern Arizona and Yosemite in northern California are managed; postwar vision of national parks as an extension of American automobile culture of freedom and convenience is disappearing; if plan is executed it would be dramatic rethinking of how parks like Grand Canyon in northern Arizona and Yosemite in northern California are managed; postwar vision of national parks as an extension of American automobile culture of freedom and convenience is disappearing; Sec Bruce Babbitt announces new restrictions on flights by small airplanes and helicopters that carry tourists over Grand Canyon; but rules are just part of long-contemplated strategy that, if planners have their way, will eventually all but eliminate cars from Grand Canyon and, one day, from other popular national parks; if plan is executed it would be dramatic rethinking of how parks like Grand Canyon in northern Arizona and Yosemite in northern California are managed; postwar vision of national parks as an extension of American automobile culture of freedom and convenience is disappearing; between 300 million and 500 million people contract malaria each year, and 10 times as many children have died from it over past decade as from all wars combined during period; malaria has remained medical catastrophe since it has received comparatively little funding for research, in part because it primarily affects poor people, and because Western drug companies doubt third world villagers would be able to pay much for new vaccine if even if it were developed; they usually take form of mea culpa message to the community; they include having drunk drivers put special license plates on their cars, making convicted shoplifters take out advertisements in local newspapers with their photos, publicly identifying men convicted of soliciting prostitutes; proponents of shaming penalties say they address needs of public weary of crime, frustrated by failures of criminal justice system and yet unwilling to pay for prison expansion; critics say penalties have circus quality that blunts whatever rehabilitative function they may have and often cross line into ridicule; photo of front lawn of man convicted of assault, bearing sign warning that 'violent felon lives here' (M)")('1997011', 'Paul Kresh, an author, critic, record producer and broadcaster who specialized in spoken-word recordings, died on Jan 12 at age 77 (M)')('1997011', "Auto insurance industry seems pleased with New Jersey Gov Christine Todd Whitman's plan to reduce premiums from 5 to 25 percent by combating fraud and offering motorists choice of policies that link savings to reduced coverage (M)")('1997011', "Editorial says Supreme Court's refusal to allow televised coverage of its proceedings has deprived public of its right to observe machinery of government at work, and denied them chance to be educated on content and merits of weighty consitutional issues")('1997011', 'At least four northern New Jersey malls have scheduled four-day clearance sale as clothing merchants in New York City prepare for weeklong sales tax reprieve (New Jersey Daily Briefing) (S)')('1997011', 'Interview with avant-garde musician Thomas Buckner, who is about to give concert at Merkin Hall in which he will sing a cycle of eight poems by a 15th-century Hindu mystic, Kabir, scored for contrabass and voice by the composer Mel Graves;
